description.narrative: The Social Security Nets Modernization Project of Ukraine bjective is to improve the performance of Ukraine’s social assistance and social services system for low-income families. All three components are linked through the definition of the Project’s Results Framework. Component one improving social assistance provision to the most vulnerable will support the Government’s reform agenda within three specific results areas, namely by: (i) accelerating poverty reduction through the gradual expansion of the GMI program; (ii) strengthening SSN administration to ensure efficient oversight and controls in both social assistance and social services delivery, and improved data management tools (MIS system) to support operational decisions and policy making; and (iii) aiding in the provision of effective social support to families in need and vulnerable families through integrating provision of benefits and services and supporting de-institutionalization of children’s services. Component two is supportive investments for institutional strengthening for administration of social assistance and social services. This component finances provision of goods, non-consulting services, consultants’ services, training and operating costs to support strengthening the institutional capacities of the Ministry of Social Policy of Ukraine and local offices to implement and monitor benefits and service. Component three is supportive investments for increasing provision of family-based care to support orphans, children deprived of parental care, disabled children and vulnerable families in four oblasts. This component finances investments to support: i) childcare de-institutionalization by providing orphans and children deprived of parental care with a family environment through foster care, adoption and placement in family-type homes; ii) transformation of residential institutions; and iii) p

condition.narrative: Finance Agreement :LA: Covenant 1 - Institutional arrangement for Project Execution | Description :Project Operational Manual hasbeen elaborated by the MoSP, reviewed and no-objected by the World Bank team and approved by the order of the MoSP in September2014. The Administrative Agreement between the MoSP, MoF and USIF has been prepared and sent for World Bank team review. At the endof October, 2014 the Bank no-objected the Administrative Agreement. After project restructuring in February 2020 and excluding USIFfrom the list of project implementing agencies, this Administrative Agreement was canceled | Frequency :CONTINUOUS

Finance Agreement :LA: Covenant 2 - Investments in Social Facilities | Description :The MoSP has prepared and signed memorandum ofunderstanding with the following pilot oblasts, namely with city of Kyiv, Kyivslaya oblast, Odeska, Ternipilska, Pivnenska,Zakarpatska and Poltavska oblasts for supervision of the investment in internats and family homes in these selected oblasts; |Frequency :CONTINUOUS

Finance Agreement :LA: Covenant 3 - Environmental and Social Safeguards | Description :The Project Operational Manual includesprovisions regulating the environmental safeguards for civil works to be implemented by USIF. However after project restructuringin February 2019 the civil works under Component 3 were excluded from the project and, consequently the USIF was excluded from theagencies that could implement project. Operational Manual was updated to reflect these changes. Thus, there are no civil worksunder the project. | Due Date :01-May-2014

Finance Agreement :LA: Covenant 4 - Review by the Bank of Procurement Decisions | Description : Procurement Progress has beentracking by the MoSP in their semiannual monitoring reports. the World bank team regularly received these reports. We have provideda waiver for submission of the Procurement Progress Report that were suppose to cover October 2014- November 2015 period. InDecember 2017 and then in December 2018 the World Bank team received Procurement progress report that covered procurement progressand issues for 2015-2018 period of project implementation. The World Bank team reviewed the report and exchanged views on thisreport | Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :LA: Covenant 5 - Withdrawal condition | Description :In 2 years the MoSP achieved 4 DLIs out of 17 DLIs anddisbursed US$70 million. All these withdrawals were made after the MoSP has submitted evidence satisfactory to the Bank thatpayments under the EEP have been made to eligible beneficiaries by the Borrower in accordance and in compliance with the proceduresset forth in the Borrower's applicable legislation. The World bank team checked the evidence submitted by the MoSP | Frequency:CONTINUOUS

title.narrative: Percentage of females receiving unemployment benefits
Percentage of females in the families provided with cash benefits under the GMI Program that was expanded to protect the poor affected by COVID-19 economic crisis
The share of individuals from the poorest decile receiving GMI increases from 10 percent in 2012 (baseline) to 17 percent in 2023
MIS collects social assistance and service programs information nationwide
GMI coverage expanded: monthly number of beneficiary families reached and maintained for at least 3 consecutive months
Number of families provided with cash benefits under the GMI Program that was expanded to protect the poor affected by COVID-19 economic crisis
The GMI budget increases at least seven-fold in nominal terms
Improved collection and use of program information in new MIS established

target.value: The MIS that process benefits and social services is operationalized nation-wide

actual.value: Development of the new integrated MIS E-Social is in progress

target.value: In 2023 thematic inspections for HUS is completed using an adequate risk-profiling system

actual.value: In Dec 2020 two inspections, one for the GMI program and one for HUS program, were completed using an adequate risk-profiling system

title.narrative: SSN system complemented with activation services for work-able GMI beneficiaries to help families graduate from benefits into employment and self-sufficiency

actual.value: On June 22, 2020 the parliament adopted legislation to launch national roll out of activation services to support labor-marketactivation of work able GMI beneficiaries from dependency on benefits to self-sufficiency.

title.narrative: Improved mechanisms of the GMI program adopted and implementation started including simplified application procedures to achieve stronger targeting accuracy and lower its delivery cost
An effective and efficient system to prevent, detect, deter and monitor error, fraud and corruption (EFC) in place
Number of children de-institutionalized and moved to alternative forms of care in four selected pilot oblasts increased by 40 percent
Number of the persons from amalgamated communities involved in consultations on new model for delivery of social benefits and service and reported that new model reflects their views increases
Increased provision of day-time services and alternative care as opposed to residential care for orphans, children deprived of parental care and children from vulnerable families in place

baseline.value: There are 3854 children in total in all 68 residential care institutions in 4 oblasts where the transformation started.

target.value: Number of children in residential care institutions in selected pilot oblasts decreased by 40 percent compared to baseline

actual.value: There are 3644 children in 68 in residential care institutions in 4 selected oblasts

title.narrative: Number of amalgamated communities that have implemented participatory budgeting increases
Share of women-entrepreneurs among able to work GMI beneficiaries who benefited from the start-up grants for small business development increases
Share of women among able to work GMI beneficiaries benefitting from the activation services increases
Number of individuals receiving unemployment benefits
Number of small entrepreneurs, operating without the creation of the legal entities, provided with temporary child benefits
Number of GMI beneficiaries that are satisfied with complementary services that were developed and agreed through participatory dialogue increases
Share of the clients satisfied with complaint handling mechanism increases
